original_theorem: Let $X_1, \dots, X_n$ be a sequence of pairwise uncorrelated random variables. Suppose each variable has the same mean $E[X_i] = \mu$ and the same finite variance $Var(X_i) = \sigma^2$. Let the sample mean be defined as $\bar{X}_n = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i$. Then, the expectation of the sample mean is $E[\bar{X}_n] = \mu$, its variance is $Var(\bar{X}_n) = \frac{\sigma^2}{n}$, and for any $\epsilon > 0$, the probability of deviation from the mean is bounded by $P(|\bar{X}_n - \mu| \ge \epsilon) \le \frac{\sigma^2}{n\epsilon^2}$.
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem mean_variance_chebyshev_of_sample_mean_uncorrelated
    -- Let n be the number of random variables, n > 0.
    {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n)
    -- Let Ω be a probability space.
    {Ω : Type*} [MeasurableSpace Ω] {P : MeasureTheory.Measure Ω} [MeasureTheory.IsProbabilityMeasure P]
    -- Let X be a sequence of n random variables.
    (X : Fin n → Ω → ℝ)
    -- Assume they all have finite variance (which implies they are L² and measurable).
    (h_memLp : ∀ i, MeasureTheory.Memℒp (X i) 2 P)
    -- Assume they share a common mean μ and variance σ².
    {μ σ² : ℝ}
    (h_mean : ∀ i, ∫ ω, X i ω ∂P = μ)
    (h_var : ∀ i, MeasureTheory.variance (X i) P = σ²)
    -- Assume they are pairwise uncorrelated.
    (h_uncorr : ∀ i j, i ≠ j → MeasureTheory.Covariance (X i) (X j) P = 0) :
  -- Define the sample mean.
  let X_bar := (n : ℝ)⁻¹ • ∑ i, X i
  -- Then the expectation of the sample mean is μ.
  (∫ ω, X_bar ω ∂P = μ) ∧
  -- The variance of the sample mean is σ²/n.
  (MeasureTheory.variance X_bar P = σ² / (n : ℝ)) ∧
  -- And for any ε > 0, Chebyshev's inequality holds.
  (∀ ε > 0, (P {ω | ε ≤ ‖X_bar ω - μ‖}).toReal ≤ σ² / (n * ε ^ 2)) := by
```
